content:
Which one of these is the more useful one?
variables (p : ℕ) [fact p.prime] {K : Type*} [field K] [fintype K] [algebra (zmod p) K] {K' : Type*} [field K'] [fintype K'] [algebra (zmod p) K']

theorem alg_equiv_of_card_eq (hKK' : fintype.card K = fintype.card K') : nonempty (K ≃ₐ[zmod p] K') :=
or
def alg_equiv_of_card_eq (hKK' : fintype.card K = fintype.card K') : K ≃ₐ[zmod p] K' :=

If the latter, how do i extract the p and n from the cardinalities? I want them in order to find the Galois field with the same cardinality.
obtain ⟨n,_,hK⟩ := finite_field.card K p, doesn't seem to work

Uniqueness of finite fields:
Any two finite fields of the same cardinality are (possibly non canonically) isomorphic

I'm trying to prove this^^
That's not provable, because if the cardinality is prime then the isomorphism is canonical ;-)
@Anupam Nayak There are at least two useful statements, I think.
You can use choose instead of obtain; choose n hn hK using finite_field.card K p,
If you know that K and K' have char p, then you want an algebra isom, like you've given.
But if you don't have those instances lying around, then you can still give a ring isomorphism without bothering about any primes.

Johan Commelin said:

If you know that K and K' have char p, then you want an algebra isom, like you've given.

I assumed that K and K' are zmod p algebras, and then proved the char p instances. That is fine?
Sure
But if the user doesn't have those zmod p algebra instances around, then a ring iso might still be nice.
So I think both variants are useful.
To be clear, you're talking not about "both" variants from the top of this thread, but about one of the variants and another unwritten one?

Johan Commelin said:

So I think both variants are useful.

ok, i'll add another statement with just the ring isomorphism

Eric Wieser said:

You can use choose instead of obtain; choose n hn hK using finite_field.card K p,

the choose tactic's mathlib documentation page should point this out

Johan Commelin said:

But if the user doesn't have those zmod p algebra instances around, then a ring iso might still be nice.

I have this now, but I was wondering if it would be more useful to have "if K is a finite field, then there exists prime p such that K is a [zmod p] algebra"? I basically do this as an intermediate step while showing the ring isomorphism, and then applying alg_equiv_of_card_eq.
Also, how do you make the hypothesis you get from choose or obtain into typeclasses as you introduce them? I would like to omit some of the haveI's
I don't think we have chooseI or obtainI
But you can just do resetI to have lean add everything it finds after you finish with the chooses.

Anupam Nayak said:

Johan Commelin said:

But if the user doesn't have those zmod p algebra instances around, then a ring iso might still be nice.

I have this now, but I was wondering if it would be more useful to have "if K is a finite field, then there exists prime p such that K is a [zmod p] algebra"? I basically do this as an intermediate step while showing the ring isomorphism, and then applying alg_equiv_of_card_eq.

If you need that step, and it's not already in mathlib, please add it! :octopus:
I'm getting a merge conflict when I did bors r+, I don't know what to do
You could merge master into your branch and see if you could fix the conflicts
Sounds like you're unlucky though, this rarely happens

git checkout master
git pull
git checkout your-branch
git merge master
# fix conflicts

Johan Commelin said:

Anupam Nayak said:

Johan Commelin said:

But if the user doesn't have those zmod p algebra instances around, then a ring iso might still be nice.

I have this now, but I was wondering if it would be more useful to have "if K is a finite field, then there exists prime p such that K is a [zmod p] algebra"? I basically do this as an intermediate step while showing the ring isomorphism, and then applying alg_equiv_of_card_eq.

If you need that step, and it's not already in mathlib, please add it! :octopus:

I'll add it tonight in a separate PR, since I don't think it'd make my current proof any shorter

Johan Commelin said:

git checkout master
git pull
git checkout your-branch
git merge master
# fix conflicts

I'll try it out
Should bors r+ work now? I think I fixed the conflict, and them synced the changes, and then did bors r+ but nothing happened
@Anupam Nayak Strange. Must be some hiccup in bors. I gave it another bors merge. It's on a merge queue now.
Yeah, bors crashed this afternoon. That was probably the cause.
